diff_hunk:
@@ -118,10 +118,14 @@ namespace tensorflow {
 //      take (A, B, A_m, B_m) as input. Among N inputs one can get N!
body:
Line 106: "Since for every input Tensorflow tensor... -> Since for every input Tensorflow tensor, the rewritten "node" gets "a" Mkl tensor, the rewritten "node" gets 2*N inputs "in total", where N is the number of inputs "of the original node".

Please note that a node is an instance of an op; so it is a node (not an op) that gets rewritten. Please update the remaining description accordingly to use "node" when referring to an instance, and "op" when referring to an op type. And I still think we should consistently use node, introducing another term "layer" to refer to a node seems unnecessary and confusing.

Please use a/an/the properly, I will not point out all this kind of English issues one by one. Please give this algorithm description section (and all comments in this PR) another pass of proofreading.

And please be consistent and always add a period in the end of a comment.
body_html:
Line 106: "Since for every input Tensorflow tensor... -> Since for every input Tensorflow tensor, the rewritten "node" gets "a" Mkl tensor, the rewritten "node" gets 2*N inputs "in total", where N is the number of inputs "of the original node".

Please note that a node is an instance of an op; so it is a node (not an op) that gets rewritten. Please update the remaining description accordingly to use "node" when referring to an instance, and "op" when referring to an op type. And I still think we should consistently use node, introducing another term "layer" to refer to a node seems unnecessary and confusing.

Please use a/an/the properly, I will not point out all this kind of English issues one by one. Please give this algorithm description section (and all comments in this PR) another pass of proofreading.

And please be consistent and always add a period in the end of a comment.
body_text:
Line 106: "Since for every input Tensorflow tensor... -> Since for every input Tensorflow tensor, the rewritten "node" gets "a" Mkl tensor, the rewritten "node" gets 2*N inputs "in total", where N is the number of inputs "of the original node".
Please note that a node is an instance of an op; so it is a node (not an op) that gets rewritten. Please update the remaining description accordingly to use "node" when referring to an instance, and "op" when referring to an op type. And I still think we should consistently use node, introducing another term "layer" to refer to a node seems unnecessary and confusing.
Please use a/an/the properly, I will not point out all this kind of English issues one by one. Please give this algorithm description section (and all comments in this PR) another pass of proofreading.
And please be consistent and always add a period in the end of a comment.
